comments: With a different offset, number of n-permutations (n>=6) of 7 objects: s, t, u, v, z, x, y with repetition allowed, containing exactly six (6) u's. - _Zerinvary Lajos_, Jun 16 2008
links: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 6..400
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Idempotent Number.
formula: a(n) = 6^n*binomial(n+6, 6). G.f.: 1/(1-6*x)^7. [Corrected by _Zerinvary Lajos_, Aug 02 2008]G.f.:1/(1-6*x)^7 [From _Zerinvary Lajos_, Aug 09 2008]
prog: (Sage)[lucas_number2(n, 6, 0)*binomial(n,6)/6^6for n in xrange(6, 22)] # [From _Zerinvary Lajos_, Mar 13 2009](MAGMA)  [6^n* Binomial(n+6, 6): n in [0..20]]; // Vincenzo Librandi, Oct 16 2011
author: _Eric W. Weisstein_
